description: News and reaction to the impact of coronavirus on Jersey and other top stories.
title: Jersey updates - BBC News
maintext:
Chief Minister John Le Fondre has said he does not believe a change in law regarding social distancing is "confusing" for islanders.
On Thursday the States made it legal again for people to enter another person's home, but the government says it "strongly advises" islanders against doing so.
"The balance has always been at what point does government interfere with what people can do in their own home.
"And there's a point which is around at what point is it proportional for the government to do so, and at what point is it proportional for government to stop doing so, and we believe that we've got to that latter point."
Senator Le Fondre said the government had come to this decision because of low levels of the virus in the island.
Deputy Richard Renouf said he did not believe it was right to continue to impose the "draconian" measures.
"It is wrong for the law still to be impinging on people's essential freedoms and their right of enjoyment to their own home."
The chief minister said there was also a "legal risk" an individual might have legally challenged the government for stopping them from having friends over.
He said it was now up to individual islanders to decide if and who they would allow in to their home.
"You don't usually allow strangers into your household. In other words you know who is coming in, and the householder is normally controlling who is coming into that house, and therefore that's where it comes back to personal choice and personal responsibility."
